title: Old-Fashioned Fun at Lancaster Fair | The Herald Traveler |
text:
With its old-fashioned country flavor, the 145th Lancaster Fair promises to fill families and fairgoers up on fried dough, homemade pies and maple cotton candy, teamed with plenty of carnival rides, live music, and agricultural fun. As one of the Grand North’s premier events, the Lancaster Fair, which runs from Sept. 2- Sept. 7 on the 65-acre Lancaster Fairgrounds in Lancaster, New Hampshire, provides families near and far with entertainment and activities for all ages, highlighted by all kinds of farm-themed fun, including the hilarious pig scramble, horse and oxen pulls, sheep dog trials and a range of 4-H exhibits.
“One of the Grand North’s most longstanding and beloved traditions, the Lancaster Fair is about community – people coming together to enjoy the final days of summer,” said Shane Beattie, vice-president of the Lancaster Fair’s Board of Directors.
Grammy-nominated and New England native country artist Jo Dee Messina is this year’s featured entertainment for Saturday, Sept. 5, at 7 p.m. Krazy Kountry Band will warm up the audience at 5 p.m. Both shows are free with paid admission.
Other grand stand shows include humorist Rusty DeWees, aka The Logger, Cruise Night, 6th Annual Fireman’s Muster, New England Championship Wrestling, and Pig Scramble, all free with paid admission, along with three paid events: the Big Rig Truck Pull, 4x4 Truck Pull, and Demolition Derby. Along with a variety of 4-H exhibits, live music and classic fair food such as grilled sausage and peppers, fairgoers will also enjoy a colorful midway with amusement rides, talent competitions, agricultural demonstrations, and exhibition halls filled with quilts, crafts, vegetables, flowers and much more. There's fun for children at the Kids Korner, which offers daily train rides, kid-friendly activities and performances by ventriloquist Sylvia Fletcher and her Magic Trunk.
“We welcome families and visitors to head north to enjoy all that the Lancaster Fair has to offer,” said Karl Stone marketing manager of NH Grand, the official visitor information source for Coos County.
The fair offers free parking, on-site camping, and one low price admission of $15 per person on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Monday that includes midway rides and music. On Saturday and Sunday, admission costs $16 per person, which includes midway rides, and seniors 70 and older are free every day of the fair. With an accompanying adult, admission for children under 36” is also free.
For more information on the Lancaster Fair, please visit: lancasterfair.com.
